content.heading: HTML Div Element
paragraphs: The <div> element is used as a container for other HTML elements.

content.heading: The <div> Element
paragraphs: The <div> element is by default a block element, meaning that it takes all available width, and comes with line breaks before and after.

content.heading: Example
paragraphs:
Lorem Ipsum
I am a div
dolor sit amet.

content.heading: <div> as a container
paragraphs: The <div> element is often used to group sections of a web page together.

content.heading: Example
paragraphs:
London

London is the capital city of England.

London has over 9 million inhabitants.

content.heading: Center align a <div> element
paragraphs: If you have a <div> element that is not 100% wide, and you want to center-align it, set the CSS margin property to auto.

content.heading: Multiple <div> elements
paragraphs: You can have many <div> containers on the same page.

content.heading: Example
paragraphs:
London

London is the capital city of England.

London has over 9 million inhabitants.

Oslo

Oslo is the capital city of Norway.

Oslo has over 700,000 inhabitants.

Rome

Rome is the capital city of Italy.

Rome has over 4 million inhabitants.

content.heading: Aligning <div> elements side by side
paragraphs: When building web pages, you often want to have two or more <div> elements side by side.

content.heading: Float
paragraphs: The CSS float property is used for positioning and formatting content and allows elements to be positioned horizontally.

content.heading: Inline-block
paragraphs: If you change the <div> element's display property from block to inline-block, the <div> elements will be displayed side by side.

content.heading: Flex
paragraphs: The CSS Flexbox Layout Module was introduced to make it easier to design flexible responsive layout structures.

content.heading: Grid
paragraphs: The CSS Grid Layout Module offers a grid-based layout system, with rows and columns, making it easier to design web pages.
